elements.content: Because of its extreme toxicity, the determination of Hg2+ in aqueous solution is an important subject for human health and environmental monitoring. In this study, a novel UIO-66-type metal–organic framework (MOF) doped with Eu3+ (isophthalic acid and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid and zirconium chloride served as the organic connectors and metal precursor, respectively) was prepared by a hydrothermal method and postsynthetic modification. The obtained lanthanide MOFs exhibited good photothermal and fluorescence stability in aqueous solution. As a luminescent probe, dispersions of the material can specifically recognize Hg2+ in many ions and have a detection limit of 8.26 nM. This novel lanthanide MOF shows great potential applications for biosensing, imaging, environmental analysis, and so on.
elements.clean_text: Because of its extreme toxicity, the determination of Hg2+ in aqueous solution is an important subject for human health and environmental monitoring. In this study, a novel UIO-66-type metal-organic framework (MOF) doped with Eu3+ (isophthalic acid and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid and zirconium chloride served as the organic connectors and metal precursor, respectively) was prepared by a hydrothermal method and postsynthetic modification. The obtained lanthanide MOFs exhibited good photothermal and fluorescence stability in aqueous solution. As a luminescent probe, dispersions of the material can specifically recognize Hg2+ in many ions and have a detection limit of 8.26 nM. This novel lanthanide MOF shows great potential applications for biosensing, imaging, environmental analysis, and so on.

elements.content: Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) (DPA = 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) with good photothermal stability is synthesized via a very simple strategy and shows relative selectivity and high sensitivity to Hg2+ in aqueous solution.
elements.clean_text: Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) (DPA = 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid) with good photothermal stability is synthesized via a very simple strategy and shows relative selectivity and high sensitivity to Hg2+ in aqueous solution.

elements.content: As an extreme-toxicity heavy element, solvated mercury­(II) can cause serious damage to organs, like brain, heart, stomach, and kidney. Because mercury can accumulate through the food chain, some human diseases, such as pink disease, Minamata diseases, and Hunter-Russell syndrome, are caused by this heavy-metal-element toxicity. Nonetheless, mercury is still widely used in battery, paints, electric equipment, and other fields. Therefore, it is of profound significance to detect Hg2+ in drinking water. So far, various complicated methods such as atomic absorption spectroscopy, cold vapor atomic fluorescence spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and electrochemical methods have been applied for Hg2+ detection. Although these methods are highly sensitive and their selectivity is outstanding, expensive equipment, complex sample preprocessing, and the requirements of professional manipulators limit their wide application. Luminescent probes outperform these models and have operational simplicity, high selectivity, sensitivity, and cost-effectiveness for Hg2+ detection. Thus, designing a novel fluorescent probe to detect Hg2+ is very important.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

As an extreme-toxicity heavy element, solvated mercury(II) can cause serious damage to organs, like brain, heart, stomach, and kidney. Because mercury can accumulate through the food chain, some human diseases, such as pink disease, Minamata diseases, and Hunter-Russell syndrome, are caused by this heavy-metal-element toxicity. Nonetheless, mercury is still widely used in battery, paints, electric equipment, and other fields. Therefore, it is of profound significance to detect Hg2+ in drinking water. So far, various complicated methods such as atomic absorption spectroscopy, cold vapor atomic fluorescence spectroscopy, inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry, and electrochemical methods have been applied for Hg2+ detection. Although these methods are highly sensitive and their selectivity is outstanding, expensive equipment, complex sample preprocessing, and the requirements of professional manipulators limit their wide application. Luminescent probes outperform these models and have operational simplicity, high selectivity, sensitivity, and cost-effectiveness for Hg2+ detection. Thus, designing a novel fluorescent probe to detect Hg2+ is very important.

elements.content: In the past few years, metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) with excellent stability, high specific surface area, tunable metrics, organic functionality, and porosity have attracted more attention. MOFs have good application prospects in various applications, such as heterogeneous catalysis, gas separation, sensing, and drug delivery. As a typical type of MOF, lanthanide MOFs with excellent lanthanide fluorescence have broad application prospects in chemical sensors, lighting devices, temperature sensing, and so on. As an efficient and flexible strategy, postsynthetic modification (PSM) has been widely utilized in the preparation of lanthanide MOFs, which could be prepared for luminescent sensors.
elements.clean_text: In the past few years, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) with excellent stability, high specific surface area, tunable metrics, organic functionality, and porosity have attracted more attention. MOFs have good application prospects in various applications, such as heterogeneous catalysis, gas separation, sensing, and drug delivery. As a typical type of MOF, lanthanide MOFs with excellent lanthanide fluorescence have broad application prospects in chemical sensors, lighting devices, temperature sensing, and so on. As an efficient and flexible strategy, postsynthetic modification (PSM) has been widely utilized in the preparation of lanthanide MOFs, which could be prepared for luminescent sensors.

elements.content: UIO-66, a zirconium terephthalate MOF, is synthesized with the use of Zr4+ and isophthalic acid (TPA). The weak dispersibility of UIO-66 limits its further application in aqueous solution. As a derivative of UIO-66, UIO-66 with free −COOH not only improves the water dispersibility in aqueous solution but also is helpful in acid catalysis, the adsorption of toxic chemicals, and the synthesis of lanthanide luminescent materials. At present, there are many methods to prepare UIO-66 with −COOH, like direct synthesis, ligand exchange, and postmodification. However, multiple steps or expensive linker materials limit the direct synthesis of UIO-66 MOFs with −COOH. Recently, Song et al. successfully directly synthesized UIO-66 with free −COOH under a mild reaction in a simple manner. In particular, two linker materials (TPA and terephthalic acid) that they chose are inexpensive. This novel strategy is very simple and convenient, which is useful for the design of novel UIO-66 MOFs with similar functionalization sites.
elements.clean_text: UIO-66, a zirconium terephthalate MOF, is synthesized with the use of Zr4+ and isophthalic acid (TPA). The weak dispersibility of UIO-66 limits its further application in aqueous solution. As a derivative of UIO-66, UIO-66 with free -COOH not only improves the water dispersibility in aqueous solution but also is helpful in acid catalysis, the adsorption of toxic chemicals, and the synthesis of lanthanide luminescent materials. At present, there are many methods to prepare UIO-66 with -COOH, like direct synthesis, ligand exchange, and postmodification. However, multiple steps or expensive linker materials limit the direct synthesis of UIO-66 MOFs with -COOH. Recently, Song et al. successfully directly synthesized UIO-66 with free -COOH under a mild reaction in a simple manner. In particular, two linker materials (TPA and terephthalic acid) that they chose are inexpensive. This novel strategy is very simple and convenient, which is useful for the design of novel UIO-66 MOFs with similar functionalization sites.

elements.content: In this work, we synthesize a novel UIO-66-type MOF from mixed linkers containing TPA and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (DPA). DPA and terephthalic acid have similar structures, which cause similar structural defects of the UIO-66 framework. The free carboxylic acid and pyridine nitrogen can improve the water dispersibility of MOFs and are considered to be functional sites. Then, a kind of lanthanide luminescent MOFs doped with Eu3+ was prepared via the PSM method. The obtained luminescent MOFs exhibit good photothermal and fluorescence stability in aqueous solution. Besides, we discover that this MOF dispersion as a luminescent probe has high selectivity and sensitivity for Hg2+ in 14 metal ions tested.
elements.clean_text: In this work, we synthesize a novel UIO-66-type MOF from mixed linkers containing TPA and 2,6-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (DPA). DPA and terephthalic acid have similar structures, which cause similar structural defects of the UIO-66 framework. The free carboxylic acid and pyridine nitrogen can improve the water dispersibility of MOFs and are considered to be functional sites. Then, a kind of lanthanide luminescent MOFs doped with Eu3+ was prepared via the PSM method. The obtained luminescent MOFs exhibit good photothermal and fluorescence stability in aqueous solution. Besides, we discover that this MOF dispersion as a luminescent probe has high selectivity and sensitivity for Hg2+ in 14 metal ions tested.

elements.content: ZrCl4, TPA, and DPA were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. Metal salts [NH4Cl, KCl, Co­(NO3)2, Cd­(NO3)2, NaNO3, Pb­(NO3)2, Cu­(NO3)2, Zn­(NO3)2, AgNO3, CaCl2, FeCl2, Al­(NO3)3, Hg­(NO3)2, Fe­(NO3)3] were obtained from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. N,N-Dimethylformamide was supplied by Tianjin Hengshan Chemical Corp. Unless otherwise stated, all chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and were used without further purification. Double-distilled water was used in this work.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Chemical and Solutions

ZrCl4, TPA, and DPA were purchased from Shanghai Aladdin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd. Metal salts [NH4Cl, KCl, Co(NO3)2, Cd(NO3)2, NaNO3, Pb(NO3)2, Cu(NO3)2, Zn(NO3)2, AgNO3, CaCl2, FeCl2, Al(NO3)3, Hg(NO3)2, Fe(NO3)3] were obtained from Tianjin Damao Chemical Reagent Factory. N,N-Dimethylformamide was supplied by Tianjin Hengshan Chemical Corp. Unless otherwise stated, all chemicals were of analytical reagent grade and were used without further purification. Double-distilled water was used in this work.

elements.content: Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy were recorded on a Bruker Tensor27 spectrometer in the wavelength range of 4000–400 cm–1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were taken on a D8 Discover diffractometer (Bruker AXS Ltd.) under experimental conditions with a Cu Kα X-ray radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was measured by NanoSEM 450 at a voltage of 3 kV. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA 409 PC/PG instrument in the temperature interval of 50–800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 in nitrogen gas. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a PHI 5700 ESCA spectrometer utilizing Al HR radiation. Fluorescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi FL-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer using a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source.
elements.clean_text:
Characterization

Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectroscopy were recorded on a Bruker Tensor27 spectrometer in the wavelength range of 4000-400 cm-1. X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were taken on a D8 Discover diffractometer (Bruker AXS Ltd.) under experimental conditions with a Cu Kα X-ray radiation. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) was measured by NanoSEM 450 at a voltage of 3 kV. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was performed on a Netzsch STA 409 PC/PG instrument in the temperature interval of 50-800 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 in nitrogen gas. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was carried out on a PHI 5700 ESCA spectrometer utilizing Al HR radiation. Fluorescence excitation and emission spectra were recorded on a Hitachi FL-4600 fluorescence spectrophotometer using a 150 W xenon lamp as the excitation source.

elements.content: MOFs were synthesized according to the previously described procedure with a small modification. The obtained MOF was expressed as UIO-66­(DPA). According to the previous literature, the crystalline quality of the MOF synthesized at a high concentration of terephthalic acid (40%) is relatively low. Thus, we chose 20% of DPA as the organic linker. Typically, 1.1672 g of ZrCl4, 0.6654 g of TPA, and 0.1675 g of DPA were dissolved in DMF (30 mL) and stirred vigorously for 10 min at room temperature, and then HCl (1.062 g) was added. After these reagents were well mixed, this mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave lined with 100 mL and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. Upon cooling, the precipitate was obtained by centrifugation, washed with DMF and acetone three times, and dried overnight.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MOFs

MOFs were synthesized according to the previously described procedure with a small modification. The obtained MOF was expressed as UIO-66(DPA). According to the previous literature, the crystalline quality of the MOF synthesized at a high concentration of terephthalic acid (40%) is relatively low. Thus, we chose 20% of DPA as the organic linker. Typically, 1.1672 g of ZrCl4, 0.6654 g of TPA, and 0.1675 g of DPA were dissolved in DMF (30 mL) and stirred vigorously for 10 min at room temperature, and then HCl (1.062 g) was added. After these reagents were well mixed, this mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave lined with 100 mL and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. Upon cooling, the precipitate was obtained by centrifugation, washed with DMF and acetone three times, and dried overnight.

elements.content: UIO-66­(DPA) (0.5 g) was dispersed in a water solution of 20 mL of EuCl3·6H2O (0.1 M), and then the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The solid was obtained by centrifugation, washed with water and acetone three times, and dried at 60 °C for at least 8 h.
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA)

UIO-66(DPA) (0.5 g) was dispersed in a water solution of 20 mL of EuCl3⋅6H2O (0.1 M), and then the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The solid was obtained by centrifugation, washed with water and acetone three times, and dried at 60 °C for at least 8 h.

elements.content: For experiments of sensing metal ions are described as follows. A total of 10 mg of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) was dispersed in 100 mL of water and then sonicated for 20 min. A total of 2 mL of the obtained dispersion and 8 mL of different metal ion aqueous solutions (1 mM) were mixed and sonicated for 20 min at room temperature for fluorescent detection.
elements.clean_text:
Ion Detection in Aqueous Solution

For experiments of sensing metal ions are described as follows. A total of 10 mg of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) was dispersed in 100 mL of water and then sonicated for 20 min. A total of 2 mL of the obtained dispersion and 8 mL of different metal ion aqueous solutions (1 mM) were mixed and sonicated for 20 min at room temperature for fluorescent detection.

elements.content: TPA, DPA, and ZrCl4, which served as the organic connectors and metal precursor, were selected to prepare UIO-66­(DPA). As shown in , the synthesis was done in one step by the in situ solvothermal method. XRD was selected to confirm the crystal structure of the obtained MOFs. In , the diffraction peaks of UIO-66­(DPA) at 7.36°, 8.49°, 14.77°, 17.07°, 25.72°, and 30.74° are in good agreement with the simulation results of the UIO-66 single-crystal structure, which implies that it is isostructural to the UIO-66 three-dimensional structure, which is composed of benzenedicarboxylate linkers and Zr6(O)4(OH)4. However, only one carboxylate arm of DPA coordinates with Zr4+, and free −COOH exists in UIO-66­(DPA) because of the asymmetrical structure of DPA. FT-IR of UIO-66­(DPA) proves this explanation. As depicted in , a new band of 1708 cm–1 appears in UIO-66­(DPA), compared with UIO-66, which is mainly from the stretching vibration of CO of free carboxylate.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Preparation and Characterization of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA)

TPA, DPA, and ZrCl4, which served as the organic connectors and metal precursor, were selected to prepare UIO-66(DPA). As shown in , the synthesis was done in one step by the in situ solvothermal method. XRD was selected to confirm the crystal structure of the obtained MOFs. In , the diffraction peaks of UIO-66(DPA) at 7.36°, 8.49°, 14.77°, 17.07°, 25.72°, and 30.74° are in good agreement with the simulation results of the UIO-66 single-crystal structure, which implies that it is isostructural to the UIO-66 three-dimensional structure, which is composed of benzenedicarboxylate linkers and Zr6(O)4(OH)4. However, only one carboxylate arm of DPA coordinates with Zr4+, and free -COOH exists in UIO-66(DPA) because of the asymmetrical structure of DPA. FT-IR of UIO-66(DPA) proves this explanation. As depicted in , a new band of 1708 cm-1 appears in UIO-66(DPA), compared with UIO-66, which is mainly from the stretching vibration of CO of free carboxylate.

elements.content: XRD patterns of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA), UIO-66­(DPA), and UIO-66­(simulated).
elements.clean_text: 1  XRD patterns of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA), UIO-66(DPA), and UIO-66(simulated).

elements.content: FT-IR spectra of UIO-66 and UIO-66­(DPA).
elements.clean_text: 2  FT-IR spectra of UIO-66 and UIO-66(DPA).

elements.content: As a novel MOF with free −COOH, UIO-66­(DPA) was applied in the preparation of lanthanide MOFs, not only further authenticating the existence of free −COOH but also implying the possible application of MOFs. After PSM, Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) presents red emissions under UV light in . This indicates that free −COOH and pyridine nitrogen of UIO-66­(DPA) have coordinated with Eu3+ and energy transfers through an “antenna effect”. The excitation and emission spectroscopy of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) is also illustrated in . When excited at 305 nm, there are many sharp emission bands at 578, 592, 615, 652, and 700 nm corresponding to the characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+, which can be ascribed to 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0–4) transitions of Eu3+ ions. The emission line at 615 nm, with the 5D0 → 7F2 transition dominating, is the main reason for the red emission color of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA). XPS analysis also proves that the Eu3+ ions were successfully coordinated with UIO-66­(DPA). The photoelectron line of Eu 3d5 at 1135.18 eV is observed in , which indicates the presence of Eu3+ in the MOFs. The photoelectron line at 400.28 eV corresponds to the N 1s spectra, which indicates the presence of a pyridine ring. Besides, the binding energies of O 1s and N 1s are moved from 531.21 to 531.33 eV and from 400.76 to 400.28 eV, respectively. These changes imply the successful coordination between free carboxylic acid and pyridine nitrogen and Eu3+ (Figure S1). The contents of europium and nitrogen are 0.40% and 2.50% in Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) (Table S1), respectively. As indicated by the XRD pattern in , the crystal structure of UIO-66­(DPA) remains unchanged after Eu3+ coordination. The morphology of the obtained materials can be examined by SEM. In Figure S2, the morphology of UIO-66­(DPA) is similar to that of UIO-66; this indicates that a moderate amount of DPA did not change the structure of the UIO-66 MOF. Moreover, the morphology of Eu3+-modified UIO-66­(DPA) is also similar to that of UIO-66. These results coincide with the changes of XRD. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis (Figure S3 and Table S3) of the obtained materials also confirms the presence of the nitrogen element and the successful incorporation of Eu3+ in Zr-MOFs. The thermal stability of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) was controlled by TGA. The TGA and DTG curves of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) are given in Figure S4. The main mass loss peak of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) appears at 550 °C, which indicates that the obtained materials exhibit excellent thermal stability.
elements.clean_text: As a novel MOF with free -COOH, UIO-66(DPA) was applied in the preparation of lanthanide MOFs, not only further authenticating the existence of free -COOH but also implying the possible application of MOFs. After PSM, Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) presents red emissions under UV light in . This indicates that free -COOH and pyridine nitrogen of UIO-66(DPA) have coordinated with Eu3+ and energy transfers through an "antenna effect". The excitation and emission spectroscopy of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) is also illustrated in . When excited at 305 nm, there are many sharp emission bands at 578, 592, 615, 652, and 700 nm corresponding to the characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+, which can be ascribed to 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 0-4) transitions of Eu3+ ions. The emission line at 615 nm, with the 5D0 → 7F2 transition dominating, is the main reason for the red emission color of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA). XPS analysis also proves that the Eu3+ ions were successfully coordinated with UIO-66(DPA). The photoelectron line of Eu 3d5 at 1135.18 eV is observed in , which indicates the presence of Eu3+ in the MOFs. The photoelectron line at 400.28 eV corresponds to the N 1s spectra, which indicates the presence of a pyridine ring. Besides, the binding energies of O 1s and N 1s are moved from 531.21 to 531.33 eV and from 400.76 to 400.28 eV, respectively. These changes imply the successful coordination between free carboxylic acid and pyridine nitrogen and Eu3+ (Figure S1). The contents of europium and nitrogen are 0.40% and 2.50% in Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) (Table S1), respectively. As indicated by the XRD pattern in , the crystal structure of UIO-66(DPA) remains unchanged after Eu3+ coordination. The morphology of the obtained materials can be examined by SEM. In Figure S2, the morphology of UIO-66(DPA) is similar to that of UIO-66; this indicates that a moderate amount of DPA did not change the structure of the UIO-66 MOF. Moreover, the morphology of Eu3+-modified UIO-66(DPA) is also similar to that of UIO-66. These results coincide with the changes of XRD. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis (Figure S3 and Table S3) of the obtained materials also confirms the presence of the nitrogen element and the successful incorporation of Eu3+ in Zr-MOFs. The thermal stability of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) was controlled by TGA. The TGA and DTG curves of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) are given in Figure S4. The main mass loss peak of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) appears at 550 °C, which indicates that the obtained materials exhibit excellent thermal stability.

elements.content: Excitation and emission spectra of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) at ambient temperature. The illustration is a corresponding luminescent image under 254 nm UV light.
elements.clean_text: 3  Excitation and emission spectra of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) at ambient temperature. The illustration is a corresponding luminescent image under 254 nm UV light.

elements.content: XPS spectra of UIO-66­(DPA) and Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA).
elements.clean_text: 4  XPS spectra of UIO-66(DPA) and Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA).

elements.content: Because the fluorescence MOFs have good fluorescence and thermal stability, the fluorescence probe is a hypothetical application. After dispersion in water, the fluorescence intensity of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) decreased, which may be related to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the water molecule O–H. The stretching vibration of the water molecule O–H can quench the fluorescence of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) (Figure S5). At the same time, the photofluorescence stability of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) in water is very important for the fluorescence probe. As can be seen from Figure S6, the fluorescence intensity of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) did not change significantly in water for a week, which indicates that Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) exhibits good fluorescence stability in aqueous solution. As shown in , the fluorescence intensity of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) as the fluorescence probe decreases significantly with Hg2+. The results suggest that Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) may be a convenient fluorescence probe for Hg2+ detection. In order to test the selectivity of the fluorescence probe to Hg2+, we studied the reactions of fluorescence probes to other metal ions, including NH4 +, K+,, Co2+, Cd2+, Na+, Pb2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Ag+, Ca2+, Fe2+, Al3+, Hg2+, and Fe3+. For fear of the response time for ion selectivity, Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) reacted adequately with different ions for 20 min. In Figure S5, the results show that Hg2+ is the only metal separator, except Fe3+, that results in significant changes in the fluorescence intensity of a Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) solution. However, the addition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) can eliminate the interference of Fe3+. In Figure S6, the fluorescence intensity of the Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) solution with Fe3+ can be restored with the existence of H2O2 because H2O2 can reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+. The presence of H2O2 cannot affect the fluorescence intensity of the Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) solution and detection of Hg2+. The results show that the probe has good selectivity for the detection of Hg2+ ions.
elements.clean_text:
Detection Selectivity and Sensitivity for Hg2+ 

Because the fluorescence MOFs have good fluorescence and thermal stability, the fluorescence probe is a hypothetical application. After dispersion in water, the fluorescence intensity of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) decreased, which may be related to the asymmetric stretching vibration of the water molecule O-H. The stretching vibration of the water molecule O-H can quench the fluorescence of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) (Figure S5). At the same time, the photofluorescence stability of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) in water is very important for the fluorescence probe. As can be seen from Figure S6, the fluorescence intensity of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) did not change significantly in water for a week, which indicates that Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) exhibits good fluorescence stability in aqueous solution. As shown in , the fluorescence intensity of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) as the fluorescence probe decreases significantly with Hg2+. The results suggest that Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) may be a convenient fluorescence probe for Hg2+ detection. In order to test the selectivity of the fluorescence probe to Hg2+, we studied the reactions of fluorescence probes to other metal ions, including NH4 +, K+,, Co2+, Cd2+, Na+, Pb2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, Ag+, Ca2+, Fe2+, Al3+, Hg2+, and Fe3+. For fear of the response time for ion selectivity, Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) reacted adequately with different ions for 20 min. In Figure S5, the results show that Hg2+ is the only metal separator, except Fe3+, that results in significant changes in the fluorescence intensity of a Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) solution. However, the addition of hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) can eliminate the interference of Fe3+. In Figure S6, the fluorescence intensity of the Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) solution with Fe3+ can be restored with the existence of H2O2 because H2O2 can reduce Fe3+ to Fe2+. The presence of H2O2 cannot affect the fluorescence intensity of the Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) solution and detection of Hg2+. The results show that the probe has good selectivity for the detection of Hg2+ ions.

elements.content: Emission spectra of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) and Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) with Hg2+ (1 mM) in aqueous media. The illustration is a corresponding luminescent image under 254 nm UV light.
elements.clean_text: 5  Emission spectra of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) and Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) with Hg2+ (1 mM) in aqueous media. The illustration is a corresponding luminescent image under 254 nm UV light.

elements.content: The detection sensitivity of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) as a fluorescence probe for Hg2+ is very important. We select different concentrations of Hg2+ to react with the fluorescence probe. As shown in , the fluorescence intensity of the probe at 615 nm decreases significantly with an increase of the Hg2+ concentration. The quenching efficiency (I 0/I) and concentrations of Hg2+ ions exhibit good linearity in the range of 10 nM to 2.5 μM (). The sensitivity and limit of detection (LOD) were derived from the Stern–Volmer equation as follows: I 0 / I − 1 = K sv [ M ] Here, I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) solutions before and after the addition of Hg2+, [M] is different concentrations of Hg2+, and K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of metal ions, and the linear relationships can be gained via fluorescence data: I 0 / I = 1.2486 + 1.3717 [ M ] ⁣ ( R = 0.99342 )
elements.clean_text: The detection sensitivity of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) as a fluorescence probe for Hg2+ is very important. We select different concentrations of Hg2+ to react with the fluorescence probe. As shown in , the fluorescence intensity of the probe at 615 nm decreases significantly with an increase of the Hg2+ concentration. The quenching efficiency (I 0/I) and concentrations of Hg2+ ions exhibit good linearity in the range of 10 nM to 2.5 μM (). The sensitivity and limit of detection (LOD) were derived from the Stern-Volmer equation as follows:  1        I   0   / I  - 1 =   K   sv    [ M ]     Here, I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) solutions before and after the addition of Hg2+, [M] is different concentrations of Hg2+, and K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of metal ions, and the linear relationships can be gained via fluorescence data: 2        I   0   / I  = 1.2486 + 1.3717  [ M ]  ⁣  ( R = 0.99342 )

elements.content: K sv can be calculated as 1.3717 × 106 M–1. The LOD of Hg2+ was determined to be 8.26 nm according to the IUPAC recommendation (3σ/slope). According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and World Health Organization, the maximum levels of Hg2+ in drinking water are 10 nM and 30 nM, respectively. Our results are below these standards. Compared with some previously reported sensors based on MOFs for the Hg2+ ion, the sensor prepared by us possesses a lower detection line (Table S4). These indicate that this luminescent MOF probe as a fluorescence material exhibits great potential in detecting Hg2+.

According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and World Health Organization, the maximum levels of Hg2+ in drinking water are 10 nM and 30 nM, respectively. Our results are below these standards. Compared with some previously reported sensors based on MOFs for the Hg2+ ion, the sensor prepared by us possesses a lower detection line (Table S4). These indicate that this luminescent MOF probe as a fluorescence material exhibits great potential in detecting Hg2+.

elements.content: The possible quenching mechanism of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) by Hg2+ ions is that DPA exhibits higher binding ability with Hg2+ than other metal ions. After the addition of Hg2+, the Eu3+ ion of MOFs can be amended by replacing it with Hg2+. The antenna effect of Eu3+ and organic ligands could be destroyed, resulting in a decrease of the fluorescence of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA). The reaction schematic diagram is given in .
elements.clean_text: The possible quenching mechanism of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) by Hg2+ ions is that DPA exhibits higher binding ability with Hg2+ than other metal ions. After the addition of Hg2+, the Eu3+ ion of MOFs can be amended by replacing it with Hg2+. The antenna effect of Eu3+ and organic ligands could be destroyed, resulting in a decrease of the fluorescence of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA). The reaction schematic diagram is given in .

elements.content: In conclusion, we have prepared a novel UIO-66-type MOF doped with Eu3+, namely, Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA), by a hydrothermal method and PSM. The luminescent MOFs have the luminescent properties of lanthanide-containing materials and have relative selectivity and high sensitivity to Hg2+ in aqueous solution. According to the quenching response of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) induced by Hg2+ ions, the LOD is 8.26 nM. We believe that this work provides a very simple and promising strategy for the design of a novel luminescent MOF for metal-ion sensing, biosensing, imaging, and other fields.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In conclusion, we have prepared a novel UIO-66-type MOF doped with Eu3+, namely, Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA), by a hydrothermal method and PSM. The luminescent MOFs have the luminescent properties of lanthanide-containing materials and have relative selectivity and high sensitivity to Hg2+ in aqueous solution. According to the quenching response of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) induced by Hg2+ ions, the LOD is 8.26 nM. We believe that this work provides a very simple and promising strategy for the design of a novel luminescent MOF for metal-ion sensing, biosensing, imaging, and other fields.

cln_elements.content:
MOFs were synthesized according to the previously described procedure with a small modification. The obtained MOF was expressed as UIO-66­(DPA). According to the previous literature, the crystalline quality of the MOF synthesized at a high concentration of terephthalic acid (40%) is relatively low. Thus, we chose 20% of DPA as the organic linker. Typically, 1.1672 g of ZrCl4, 0.6654 g of TPA, and 0.1675 g of DPA were dissolved in DMF (30 mL) and stirred vigorously for 10 min at room temperature, and then HCl (1.062 g) was added. After these reagents were well mixed, this mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave lined with 100 mL and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. Upon cooling, the precipitate was obtained by centrifugation, washed with DMF and acetone three times, and dried overnight.

Preparation of Eu<sup>3+</sup>@UIO-66­(DPA)

UIO-66­(DPA) (0.5 g) was dispersed in a water solution of 20 mL of EuCl3·6H2O (0.1 M), and then the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The solid was obtained by centrifugation, washed with water and acetone three times, and dried at 60 °C for at least 8 h.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of MOFs

MOFs were synthesized according to the previously described procedure with a small modification. The obtained MOF was expressed as UIO-66(DPA). According to the previous literature, the crystalline quality of the MOF synthesized at a high concentration of terephthalic acid (40%) is relatively low. Thus, we chose 20% of DPA as the organic linker. Typically, 1.1672 g of ZrCl4, 0.6654 g of TPA, and 0.1675 g of DPA were dissolved in DMF (30 mL) and stirred vigorously for 10 min at room temperature, and then HCl (1.062 g) was added. After these reagents were well mixed, this mixture was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave lined with 100 mL and heated at 180 °C for 24 h. Upon cooling, the precipitate was obtained by centrifugation, washed with DMF and acetone three times, and dried overnight.

Preparation of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA)

UIO-66(DPA) (0.5 g) was dispersed in a water solution of 20 mL of EuCl3⋅6H2O (0.1 M), and then the mixture was stirred at 80 °C for 24 h. The solid was obtained by centrifugation, washed with water and acetone three times, and dried at 60 °C for at least 8 h.

cln_elements.content:
As a novel MOF with free −COOH, UIO-66­(DPA) was applied in the preparation of lanthanide MOFs, not only further authenticating the existence of free −COOH but also implying the possible application of MOFs. After PSM, Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) presents red emissions under UV light in . This indicates that free −COOH and pyridine nitrogen of UIO-66­(DPA) have coordinated with Eu3+ and energy transfers through an “antenna effect”. The excitation and emission spectroscopy of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) is also illustrated in . When excited at 305 nm, there are many sharp emission bands at 578, 592, 615, 652, and 700 nm corresponding to the characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+, which can be ascribed to 5D0 → 7F J (J = 0–4) transitions of Eu3+ ions. The emission line at 615 nm, with the 5D0 → 7F2 transition dominating, is the main reason for the red emission color of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA). XPS analysis also proves that the Eu3+ ions were successfully coordinated with UIO-66­(DPA). The photoelectron line of Eu 3d5 at 1135.18 eV is observed in , which indicates the presence of Eu3+ in the MOFs. The photoelectron line at 400.28 eV corresponds to the N 1s spectra, which indicates the presence of a pyridine ring. Besides, the binding energies of O 1s and N 1s are moved from 531.21 to 531.33 eV and from 400.76 to 400.28 eV, respectively. These changes imply the successful coordination between free carboxylic acid and pyridine nitrogen and Eu3+ (Figure S1). The contents of europium and nitrogen are 0.40% and 2.50% in Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) (Table S1), respectively. As indicated by the XRD pattern in , the crystal structure of UIO-66­(DPA) remains unchanged after Eu3+ coordination. The morphology of the obtained materials can be examined by SEM. In Figure S2, the morphology of UIO-66­(DPA) is similar to that of UIO-66; this indicates that a moderate amount of DPA did not change the structure of the UIO-66 MOF. Moreover, the morphology of Eu3+-modified UIO-66­(DPA) is also similar to that of UIO-66. These results coincide with the changes of XRD. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis (Figure S3 and Table S3) of the obtained materials also confirms the presence of the nitrogen element and the successful incorporation of Eu3+ in Zr-MOFs. The thermal stability of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) was controlled by TGA. The TGA and DTG curves of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) are given in Figure S4. The main mass loss peak of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) appears at 550 °C, which indicates that the obtained materials exhibit excellent thermal stability.

The detection sensitivity of Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) as a fluorescence probe for Hg2+ is very important. We select different concentrations of Hg2+ to react with the fluorescence probe. As shown in , the fluorescence intensity of the probe at 615 nm decreases significantly with an increase of the Hg2+ concentration. The quenching efficiency (I 0/I) and concentrations of Hg2+ ions exhibit good linearity in the range of 10 nM to 2.5 μM (). The sensitivity and limit of detection (LOD) were derived from the Stern–Volmer equation as follows: I 0 / I − 1 = K sv [ M ] Here, I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the Eu3+@UIO-66­(DPA) solutions before and after the addition of Hg2+, [M] is different concentrations of Hg2+, and K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of metal ions, and the linear relationships can be gained via fluorescence data: I 0 / I = 1.2486 + 1.3717 [ M ] ⁣ ( R = 0.99342 )

K sv can be calculated as 1.3717 × 106 M–1. The LOD of Hg2+ was determined to be 8.26 nm according to the IUPAC recommendation (3σ/slope). According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and World Health Organization, the maximum levels of Hg2+ in drinking water are 10 nM and 30 nM, respectively. Our results are below these standards. Compared with some previously reported sensors based on MOFs for the Hg2+ ion, the sensor prepared by us possesses a lower detection line (Table S4). These indicate that this luminescent MOF probe as a fluorescence material exhibits great potential in detecting Hg2+.
cln_elements.clean_text:
As a novel MOF with free -COOH, UIO-66(DPA) was applied in the preparation of lanthanide MOFs, not only further authenticating the existence of free -COOH but also implying the possible application of MOFs. After PSM, Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) presents red emissions under UV light in . This indicates that free -COOH and pyridine nitrogen of UIO-66(DPA) have coordinated with Eu3+ and energy transfers through an "antenna effect". The excitation and emission spectroscopy of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) is also illustrated in . When excited at 305 nm, there are many sharp emission bands at 578, 592, 615, 652, and 700 nm corresponding to the characteristic emission peaks of Eu3+, which can be ascribed to 5D0 → 7F J  (J = 0-4) transitions of Eu3+ ions. The emission line at 615 nm, with the 5D0 → 7F2 transition dominating, is the main reason for the red emission color of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA). XPS analysis also proves that the Eu3+ ions were successfully coordinated with UIO-66(DPA). The photoelectron line of Eu 3d5 at 1135.18 eV is observed in , which indicates the presence of Eu3+ in the MOFs. The photoelectron line at 400.28 eV corresponds to the N 1s spectra, which indicates the presence of a pyridine ring. Besides, the binding energies of O 1s and N 1s are moved from 531.21 to 531.33 eV and from 400.76 to 400.28 eV, respectively. These changes imply the successful coordination between free carboxylic acid and pyridine nitrogen and Eu3+ (Figure S1). The contents of europium and nitrogen are 0.40% and 2.50% in Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) (Table S1), respectively. As indicated by the XRD pattern in , the crystal structure of UIO-66(DPA) remains unchanged after Eu3+ coordination. The morphology of the obtained materials can be examined by SEM. In Figure S2, the morphology of UIO-66(DPA) is similar to that of UIO-66; this indicates that a moderate amount of DPA did not change the structure of the UIO-66 MOF. Moreover, the morphology of Eu3+-modified UIO-66(DPA) is also similar to that of UIO-66. These results coincide with the changes of XRD. The energy-dispersive X-ray (EDX) analysis (Figure S3 and Table S3) of the obtained materials also confirms the presence of the nitrogen element and the successful incorporation of Eu3+ in Zr-MOFs. The thermal stability of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) was controlled by TGA. The TGA and DTG curves of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) are given in Figure S4. The main mass loss peak of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) appears at 550 °C, which indicates that the obtained materials exhibit excellent thermal stability. 

The detection sensitivity of Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) as a fluorescence probe for Hg2+ is very important. We select different concentrations of Hg2+ to react with the fluorescence probe. As shown in , the fluorescence intensity of the probe at 615 nm decreases significantly with an increase of the Hg2+ concentration. The quenching efficiency (I 0/I) and concentrations of Hg2+ ions exhibit good linearity in the range of 10 nM to 2.5 μM (). The sensitivity and limit of detection (LOD) were derived from the Stern-Volmer equation as follows:  1        I   0   / I  - 1 =   K   sv    [ M ]     Here, I 0 and I are the fluorescence intensities of the Eu3+@UIO-66(DPA) solutions before and after the addition of Hg2+, [M] is different concentrations of Hg2+, and K sv is the quenching effect coefficient of metal ions, and the linear relationships can be gained via fluorescence data: 2        I   0   / I  = 1.2486 + 1.3717  [ M ]  ⁣  ( R = 0.99342 )      

 K sv can be calculated as 1.3717 × 106 M-1. The LOD of Hg2+ was determined to be 8.26 nm according to the IUPAC recommendation (3σ/slope). According to the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency and World Health Organization, the maximum levels of Hg2+ in drinking water are 10 nM and 30 nM, respectively. Our results are below these standards. Compared with some previously reported sensors based on MOFs for the Hg2+ ion, the sensor prepared by us possesses a lower detection line (Table S4). These indicate that this luminescent MOF probe as a fluorescence material exhibits great potential in detecting Hg2+.

metadata.title:
Eu3+-Postdoped UIO-66-Type Metal–Organic
Framework as a Luminescent Sensor for Hg2+ Detection in
Aqueous Media
